incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

Deploys and image builds can fail in the "Waiting for Depot builder" step. If you're still stuck in "Waiting for Depot builder", stop and restart your deploy, or use `fly deploy --depot=false`.

incident_updates.body: The issue is resolved.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.

This incident has been resolved. It was caused by a recent `flyctl` update and only apps deployed with flyctl version v0.3.227 were affected. We have deployed a server-side workaround.

We are currently investigating issues with some apps on IPv6.
This incident has been resolved.
Our metrics show that machines API has mostly recovered. We're still working through a small number of degraded Managed Postgres clusters.

We have identified and implemented a fix for the root cause of this incident and are monitoring the results. Machines API should be seeing recovery.

On the Managed Postgres side, New MPG creates should be working. A small number of clusters remain degraded, or are experiencing connectivity issues. We are continuing to restore these as quickly as possible.

We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue. Users will still see elevated error rates creating new apps, machines, and MPG clusters, as well as other API operations. Users may also see newly created machines remaining in a `created` state for an extended period before starting.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.

We are continuing to see elevated errors with creating new apps, new MPG clusters, and setting secrets. A small number of MPG clusters continue to see connectivity errors. We are continuing to work on these issues.

We continue to see increased error rates creating new apps and MPG clusters, as well as with setting secrets. We are continuing to work to resolve these issues. 

A small number of MPG clusters are still experiencing connectivity issues. We are working to restore these to a healthy state as quickly as possible.
We have identified some continuing issues with creating new apps and secrets and are working to resolve them.

Our monitoring indicates that machines API, flyctl and dashboard access should have recovered. Some Managed Postgres clusters may still be affected -- Rest assured that your cluster's data is intact while we are working to recover them to a working state.
We have identified and implemented a fix for the API outage. Some Managed Postgres clusters may be affected as a secondary effect and we are currently working to restore them.
We are investigating an increase in errors that affects numerous API endpoints including the Machines API, flyctl and dashboard.

An upstream provider experienced network issues in the SJC region. Apps on affected hosts and API clients near SJC may have experienced degraded connectivity and elevated error rates between 18:38 to 19:03 and 20:02 to 20:26 UTC. The issue is now resolved.
This incident has been resolved.
A new version of Flyctl has been released with a fix for this issue. Users on flyctl version v0.3.214 should upgrade to Flyctl v0.3.216 using `fly version update`.

We have identified an issue in the latest Flyctl release (v0.3.214)  that impacts commands using wireguard connectivity for some users. Impacted users may see `tunnel unavailable` or `no such organization` errors when running commands like `fly wireguard` , `fly proxy` or `fly mpg proxy` with their default Personal org. We are working on a fix.

 In the meantime, impacted users can install the previous flyctl version with `curl -L https://fly.io/install.sh | sh -s 0.3.213`. Users that normally install flyctl via package managers (eg. homebrew) should uninstall the package manager version first to avoid conflicts.

incidents.name: Static egress IPv6 issues in BOM

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

We have identified an upstream issue that prevented static egress IPv6 addresses in BOM from reaching parts of the Internet and are currently working with upstreams for a fix. Machines without a static egress IPv6 address are not affected. For affected machines, consider forcing IPv4 for outbound connectivity or de-allocating the egress IP if not needed via `fly m egress-ip release`.
This incident has been resolved.
The maintenance has been completed and we are monitoring the results.
One of our upstream providers is performing an emergency network maintenance in BOM. Apps in BOM may experience temporary connectivity issues.
A temporary fix in place and restores are back to working.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

incidents.name: "unauthorized" errors when starting some Fly builds

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

We're continuing to investigate the issue. Both legacy Fly builders and Buildkit builders are affected by this - if you're running into this error, please try deploying with `--depot=true`. (The default `fly deploy` and `fly launch` use Depot builders, which remain unaffected by this issue.)

We're investigating reports of "unauthorized" errors when doing `fly deploy` operations using the `--depot=false` parameter. This is not enabled by default, and Depot builders are unaffected. If you're seeing this error, try deploying with `--depot=true` to work around problems with legacy Fly builders.

incident_updates.body:
Between approximately 10:58 UTC and 11:25 UTC, Fly.io experienced degraded proxy performance in multiple regions, including IAD, FRA, EWR and LHR.
During this period, users may have observed intermittent connection errors or elevated response times.

The elevated traffic has subsided, and proxy performance is back to normal.

Any users still encountering errors deploying, please check and make sure your flyctl version is >=v0.3.180, and update with `fly version update` if not.

We have seen a strong decrease in errors for most users. We are seeing some 401 errors still for users using old versions of flyctl.

Users encountering a 401 error and using a version under v0.3.180, should run `flyctl version update` to update to the latest flyctl version.

A fix has been deployed and we are monitoring the results. We are seeing a decrease in 401 / 499 errors when deploying. 

This issue primarily impacted users deploying apps via the Fly Dashboard, deploys using flyctl versions lower than v0.3.180, and deploys involving building very large images.
Users may notice intermittent 4XX errors while pushing to Fly registry.

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

We've applied mitigations to the impacted regions and are seeing a significant improvement in packet loss. Most regions are back to normal networking performance. 
BOM (Mumbai) has improved, but continues to see slightly elevated loss. We are continuing to monitor for full recovery

We are working with our networking providers to restore normal operation. We are seeing an improvement in packet loss in most regions, though users may see intermittent loss at this time.

 BOM (Mumbai), CDG (Paris), NRT (Tokyo), SIN (Singapore) are still seeing higher rates of packet loss. Users may see degraded networking performance connecting to or from machines in those regions.
We are currently investigating elevated packet loss between a number of regions. Users may see degraded network performance when connecting to or from their machines.
This incident has been resolved.

New app logs are once again stably flowing into the fly-metrics.net dashboard. Users should see and be able to search all app logs from 22:30 UTC onwards. We are continuing to monitor the customer logs cluster to ensure continued stability.

Not all historical logs were able to be backfilled. Many users will see missing or incomplete logs for the period between 08:00 - 22:30 UTC Oct-06-2025.
We are continuing to backfill historic logs into fly-metrics.net.  New logs will be accessible once the backfill is complete.

We have applied a fix and historic logs are now backfilling into fly-metrics.net.  New logs will be accessible once the backfill is complete.

Customers can continue view live logs for their apps using the `flyctl logs` command and from the logs tab of their app page at Fly.io/dashboard.

We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue. Searchable logs in the fly-metrics.net Grafana board remain unavailable at this time.
